content: The environmental impacts of human activity, particularly related to buildings, have become a major concern in recent decades. Buildings, including residential, commercial, and government structures, are recognized as a significant source of environmental impact due to resource consumption, waste production, and direct effects on occupants. This includes electricity usage, water consumption, and the use of construction materials with complex supply chains. Buildings have significant environmental and financial costs, accounting for 40% of energy consumption in the US and producing 40% of greenhouse gas emissions. Their location affects stormwater management and transportation energy use. Indoor air quality impacts occupant health and productivity. Green building addresses environmental and health impacts in buildings, improving indoor air quality and reducing pollutants. It has gained interest since the 1990s, involving various stakeholders like construction firms, building owners, lawmakers, and government agencies. The report discusses green building, federal policies, and programs related to it, including its definition, environmental impact areas, tools for compliance, implementation issues, and key authorities. The modern practice of green building emerged in the 1990s, with organizations like the American Institute of Architects and the U.S. Green Building Council playing significant roles. The "Greening of the White House" project was a notable federal green building initiative in that decade. The concept of green building has evolved from the "Greening of the White House" project in the 1990s to encompass environmentally conscious design principles and practices aimed at reducing harmful impacts of the built environment. Green building efforts vary along a design and performance continuum, with some focusing on greatly reducing environmental impacts, such as zero-impact or minus-impact buildings, while others may use the term as a marketing tool, known as "greenwashing." Green building is an integrated approach to design, construction, and operations that reduces the environmental footprint of buildings. It is a relative concept, aiming for greener than average structures through various techniques and strategies. This approach can be applied to any type of building, seeking improvements in environmental performance. Green building techniques, including innovative technologies and design features, are often decided in the design phase to reduce the environmental footprint of buildings. The terms green building and sustainable building are used interchangeably, with sustainable building aiming for smaller environmental footprints to not hinder future human activity and ecosystems. Green building, also known as high-performance building, aims to maintain small environmental footprints to support future human activity and ecosystem functioning. In 2015, the ICC and ASHRAE announced a partnership to integrate Standard 189.1 into the 2018 version of the IgCC, aligning it with the LEED rating system.
